p.s: The way the text is narrated, it lets the reader jump in the point of view of a racist and in the end it shows how paranoid Delaney must have acted.
In the first place there is a switch up between the connotation of the words.

Until Delaney realizes that the man at the Cherrystones is a Mexican the narrator stops using neutral descriptions (l. 10ff.) and starts using bad connotated formulations like a violent jerk (l. 45) for the move of the Mexican to free himself off the hold of Delaney.
Moreover he (Delaney) is also interpreting things in the actions of the Mexican like he is mocking him or that he has a reason (l. 56f.).
This goes so far, that Delaney is feared for his life like you can see in the climax: [...] so keyed up he was ready to spring at him, tackle him, fight to the death (l. 56f.).
Consequently you can see how Delaney is influenced by his prejudesprejudices which are leading him to act racist like in line 39: You don't belong here.

This setencesentence got a double sided meaning because on the one hand he tells the Mexican that he isntisn't alowedallowed to be in their gated community or the lawn of the Cherrystones but on the other hand it could also I mean that he doesn't belong to the USA, which is a very racist statement.

DelaneysDelaney's racist thinking can also be seen in a climax in line 54: The man was a thief, a liar, the stinking occupant of a stinking sleeping bag in the state forest, a trespasser, a polluter, a Mexican which shows that the last named thing, his origin, is the worst for him.
After the incident, he reflects his behaviour and realizes, parralel to the reader, how crazy he had acted.
The narration lets the reader feel like Delaney, because when he's not driven by his emotions anymore, he feels neutral about him like in the beginning.
So it can be said Delaney isn't that outgrown racist like in the end, because he knows that he had been wrong and was led by his prejudesprejudices.
In the end of the excerpt Delaney recognizes a letter of Jack Jardine, the president of their community, and it says that there will be a meeting on security.
This is very ironical because in the text there is a perfect example of the irrational paranoid thinking which had led the community to build a wall around their houses and become a gated community.
To come to an end you could say that Delaney comes to terms with his emotional expieriencesexperiences like the car theft by blaming it on Mexicans and developing prejudesprejudices.
In the chapter you can see the middle of his racist character development through the book.
